dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, the two countries will resume military-to-military communication, thereby reducing the chances of an accidental conflict, and China will do more to restrict the export of chemicals used to make the powerful synthetic opioid fentanyl a major cause of death in the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping slightly] But if we *maintain* them, like, it could raise the cost of our typical household consumption basket by about half a percentage point, which doesn't sound like a lot, but it adds up, you know?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since imported goods account for about 12% of the US household-consumption basket, the removal of the Trump tariffs would lower the cost of that basket by about half a percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just direct consumer goods either. A significant portion – about 40% – of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods. So, keeping these tariffs actually *raises* input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just direct consumer goods either. A significant portion - about forty percent - of U S imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods. So, keeping these tariffs actually raises input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. So, it's not just that Chinese goods get more expensive, but then our own American-made products, because they rely on those parts, also become more expensive?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, the prices of many American-made products and services in the US household-consumption basket would also decline.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! And then, uh, it also reduces competitive pressure on other producers in places like Mexico, India, or Vietnam, which could, in turn, lead to higher prices from *those* countries too.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Chinese imports become cheaper, competitive pressure on other producers would rise, leading to lower prices on goods made in Mexico, India, Vietnam, and even the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point. Put another way, this would be equivalent of an increase in US household income by more than $250 billion per year (1% of US GDP in 2022).

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty significant. And it's not just about American consumers; US firms also stand to lose. If the US were to reverse these tariffs, the article suggests China would likely maintain *theirs* on our goods.

dialogue_turns.text: Which then, you know, hurts our competitiveness in the Chinese market, right? Like, jobs and incomes for US exporters, and even their suppliers.
